citation.article-title: Lutibacter maritimus sp. nov., isolated from a tidal flat sediment
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Lutibacter maritimus sp. nov.
Lutibacter maritimus (ma.ri′ti.mus. L. masc. adj. maritimus of the sea, marine, maritime).
Cells are Gram-staining-negative, aerobic, non-flagellated, non-gliding and rod-shaped, 0.3–0.8 μm in diameter and 1.0–5.0 μm in length.
Colonies on MA are circular with entire margins, convex and yellow in colour.
Carotenoid pigments are produced, but flexirubin-type pigments are not produced.
Growth occurs at 4 and 37 °C (optimum 25–30 °C), but not at 40 °C.
Growth occurs at pH 5.0 (optimum pH 7.0–8.0), but not at pH 4.5.
Growth occurs in the presence of 0.5–5.0 % (w/v) NaCl (optimum approximately 2.0 % (w/v) NaCl).
Mg2+ ions are required for growth.
Maltose is utilized as sole carbon and energy source, but l-arabinose, l-glutamate, d-mannose, sucrose, trehalose, d-xylose, acetate, benzoate, l-malate, salicin and formate are not.
The major polar lipids are phosphatidylethanolamine and three unidentified lipids.
The major cellular fatty acids (>10 % of total fatty acids) are iso-C15 : 0 and C15 : 1ω6c.
Other phenotypic characteristics are given in Table 1.
The type strain, S7-2T (=KCTC 22635T=CCUG 57524T), was isolated from a tidal flat sediment at Saemankum on the west coast of Korea.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 34.6 mol% (determined by HPLC).
